course.subject: COMP
course.name: Internet Computing
course.description: Technologies and standards for World Wide Web (WWW), user interfaces and Browsers, authoring tools, Internet protocols, Internet servers, database connectivity, Robots, Search engines, server-side programming, client-side programming, security and privacy, recent advances.
course.prerequisites: COMP 2012 OR COMP 2012H

reviews.author: B.T.
reviews.title: Professor a bit overrated. A good course overall.
reviews.comment_content:
Refer to the 2022 Spring Review for Gibson for the detailed breakdown of lecture materials.

One point that I dislike about the contents, apart from being quite out-dated, is that the topics are not inter-related from class to class. It sometimes jumps to JS, then jumps back to more on CSS, then more on JS, then HTML forms, then backend, then suddenly more on frontend... A bit hard to follow the logic. But if you can clear up your mind and understand everything, it should be fine with the ireegular order of topics.

Also, this course is perhaps one of the few decentralized course in HKUST. Different professors will introduce way different topics. Therefore, suggest you look into other reviews to comapre the detailed contents that each teaches if you think the topics will be one of your concern for enrollment and if you can waitlist into this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Firslty, showing my background, I have taken various "famous" professors in CSE, such as Dave Rossiter, Desmond, Kenneth, DY Leung, etc. This is the first time (and last, ofc.) taking Gibson's class. Maybe I expected too much, or maybe I thought his teaching would be identical to Rossiter's, anyhow, I don't feel his lecture enjoyable. I will say he is an average instructor.

The professor did have his heart to teach, and prepare pretty well for each class. However, I fell asleep in almost every lecture. Probably due to the fact that lecture time is TuTh 5-6pm, and in LT-K where the cusions are very nice. The professor tried to make jokes from time to time but I don't think them particularly funny.

Also, this is a bit personal, but I just don't like Gibson's intonation. His accent is fine, pronunciation is claer, but his way of presenting linkages between sentences make me hard to concentrate and to digest what every single word that he speaks.

After the add-drop, there are about only 10 students in LT-K where the enrollment size is in full capacity 80. This also shows that Gibson may not be as enjoyable as we expect.

Even though, he delivers the content and maintains the logistics well. One extra comment is that the TA graded the lab and project really, really slow. It took nearly two months to grade the first lab.
reviews.comment_grading:
Labs 3 x 10% (4 choose 3 best)
Project 30%
Final Exam 40%

The four labs are hammer game, jumping game, gem game and chatroom. Project is to develop a web game with real-time connection between two players. (Yes..... I don't know why the professor is so obsessed with games. Anyway, they are fine)

Labs are easy. Follow the lab videos and check with the grading scheme to score full.

Project is tricky, in the sense that you may think everyone is super good, doing cool games. Indeed, it's not the case. Follow the marking scheme and do every single element and then you will be already top 10%. This is not a game programming course at the end of the day.

Final exam: A comp1021 style of final exam, tricky but easy questions. Open book open notes closed internet and closed programming. However, I don't know what's the point of testing us syntax-related stuff and some for-loops or some functions in javascript. Or maybe there is no other things to test at all? Idk.

My grade:
Labs: Full 30% (means are higher than 95% for each lab, and considering choose 3 out of 4, mean for total lab should around full)
Project: 240 out of 250 (mean 230)
Final Exam: 93 (mean 68.4)

Letter grade: A+
Very good indeed. I was expecting an A only.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not bad. Labs have videos released where you can just follow all and write 2-3 lines to get full score.

The last lab may need to spent more time but is fine. The project is the most heavy part where you need to spend days and nights with your groupmates to work on it.

One key tip: Actually not many groups make wonderful games amid Gibson showed many samples at the beginning. Follow all the grading criteria and secure most of the scores before making some cool stuff. Fyr, my game is just an extension of a lab because we did't have enough time to make it nice, yet it fulfills all grading criteria and just lose 10 out of 250 points on "gaming experience".

reviews.author: Kabul
reviews.title: Nice course.
reviews.comment_content:
HTML, CSS, JavaScript, jQuery, SVG, XML, AJAX, PHP, Bootstrap, JSON, Cookies, Node.js, everything you can name related to web development. The content is very hands-on and practical, and I'm glad that I finally have a COMP course that teaches me how to code...

The course is beginner-friendly and no prerequisite knowledge in web programming is needed. Dave has amended the course topics to remove technologies that are obsolete and include those that are more recent and commonly used. It still does not cover the more advanced technologies such as React, AngularJS and Vue.js, but this is fair enough given the limited time for the course. If you wanna be a full stack developer you probably also need to learn Linux, Apache/Nginx, depending on which stack you would like to specialize in. But I guess you'd need to explore them by yourselves.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The COVID-19 pandemic has made us switch to online learning this semester. However, so far I think Dave has done a very good job in delivering course materials and helping us consolidate what we've learned. Dave made "high-efficiency" videos that are clear, concise and suitable for lazy guys like me. He also provided a Zoom session every week and asked a few basic questions to help us revise what we've just learned. Some questions involved tricky points we easily miss out and asking questions is indeed a very nice way to bring them out.

PS It was so funny that Dave forgot to escape the characters in his chatroom code example and somebody else in class easily did an XSS hacking during his demo LMAO. Then a message box kept hovering over the web page.
reviews.comment_grading:
üíª 30% - 3 Hand-in Labs (Each 10%)
‚úèÔ∏è 30% - Late Midterm
üíª 40% - Project (8% Proposal, 32% Project Deliverable)

Extra 0.6% for every question you answer right in the Zoom review sessions, and he asked 48 questions in total. So a maximum of 28.8% bonus points could be added on top of your overall score. That's a hell lot of points!

The midterm was a little online Canvas quiz consisting of 15 multiple choice questions, randomly drawn from a super-set of question database. Everyone would get a slightly different subset of questions. It was conducted quite late towards the end of the Spring semester, in May, so it actually covered most of the lecture materials for the whole semester. Open-book and open Internet. But only Chrome was allowed and of course no messaging. The midterm was easy but tricky, with the mean landing on only 61.7/100. We've got some interesting questions though, like one asking us to go to a web page and check the expiry date of a cookie, and another one asking us to send a HEAD HTTP request and check the last modified date of an HTML file. This would only be possible when we have an online midterm like this. But on the other hand Dave also liked to ask "eye test" questions such as spotting a missing speech mark, which I personally think are silly since we now have powerful IDEs that can easily fix all these.

Mean = 61.7/100
SD = 17.5
Max = 92.4
Min = 14.2

As for the project, 8% of the total score is allocated to the project proposal. As soon as you've written something intelligible, you should be able to get it. The remaining 32% is for the actual project deliverable. You can either do great in a project with only client-side programming, or do okay-ish in both the client-side and server-side programming to get full score.

Mean = 26.6 / 32 (Does not include 0's)
SD = 8.4

I got 86.67/100 in the midterm, 22.8/28.8 for bonus Zoom questions, 28/32 for the project (got some bugs ‚òπÔ∏è), and full marks in the lab assignments.

Final grade: Pass
So I dunno what I actually got. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload mainly lies on the lab assignments and the course project.

There were a total of 5 labs, but only lab 2 to lab 4 needed to be submitted. Since it's online instruction they've basically become assignments with strictly defined marking schemes.

üî∑ Lab 1
A number guessing game introducing basic CSS, JavaScript and DOM handling.
üî∂ Lab 2
A hammer game involving jQuery and the use of timer.
üî∂ Lab 3
A obstacle jumping game involving SVG and animations.
üî∂ Lab 4
A movie catalog allowing users to search and sort Marvel movies from an XML database. Mainly involved PHP, Bootstrap and XML handling.
üî∑ Lab 5
A single-page application allowing users to view, filter, sort and add Pok√©mon. Mainly involved PHP, Bootstrap, jQuery, XML and AJAX.

üî∑ Hand-in Lab
üî∂ Self-Learning Lab

Most of the labs were easy and could be finished in a couple of hours. Mean score were crazily high though, so make sure don't lose any easy marks here.

Everything else is simple. but all evil lies in the course project! We can either do it alone or form a group of 2 - 3 people. The topic can either be an extension from the lab (probably can only score an okay-ish mark if we do that) or any other fancy topics we like. At the end we've gotta submit to link to the main page of our website and make a video to introduce what it does / make an appointment to demonstrate to Dave real-time. The difficulty actually depends on the selection of the topic and the group mates. It's still very challenging, however, since the project is indeed assessed in terms of complexity and most of the time the content taught in class is just not enough for a complex project. Specifically the server-side programming such as PHP and Node.js is only taught in brief and there is a lot we have to explore by ourselves if we wanna do a project that includes server-side programming.

But overall the workload is lighter than most of the other COMP courses.

reviews.author: Kpyau
reviews.comment_content:
Use of HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Jquery, SVG, PHP

Three assignments: 12%(jQuery)+18%(SVG)+18%(PHP)=48%
One Midterm: 18%
One Final 34%
reviews.comment_teaching: Kenneth is a good teacher. It is easy for us to follow as he speaks English fluently. Each lesson is short. If he finished teaching the slides, we can go early. Has a review session for us to practice some exam question.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade
Almost full marks in three assignments
mid term and exam scores are around mean
Got B+
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is low
Make sure you attend the lab because the TA will guide you do the lab which is related to the assignments
If you attend all the labs, the assignments are done like 70%

reviews.author: DrainGang
reviews.title: Good course besides the exam.
reviews.comment_content:
HTML
Images in Browsers
Basic CSS
CSS Animations
Introduction to JavaScript
Handling the DOM
Introduction to JavaScript
jQuery
Using Timers
More on CSS and jQuery
Introduction to SVG
SVG and CSS Animations
Controlling CSS Animations
More on SVG
HTML Canvas
More on JavaScript
Making Games With Sprites
Basic Module Pattern
A Quick Look at JSON
Basic HTTP Process
Getting Started With Node.js
Using JavaScript Promises
Building a Simple Server
Using HTML Forms
Cookies
Using AJAX
A SPA Example
Web Sessions
Using WebSocket
Basic PHP
Storing Things on Browsers
RESTful APIs
More on Promises
Posting Form Data
MVC in Express

Basics for web development, includes front-end and back-end. Pretty useful with a lot of hands-on opportunities, rare for your average COMP course in UST.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Online lectures only. 2-3 Videos posted every week. Powerpoints are very detailed so watching the videos isn't really necessary to be honest.

However, since the lecture is covered by Gibson and Professor Rossiter, the videos (when you do need them) are very well made, examples are explained in even MORE detail, and you can watch them at your own pace. Very good!
reviews.comment_grading:
Labs (30%): 4 labs, only the 3 highest ones are counted, the first 3 labs are significantly easier than the 4th, expect most people to have 100% on all 3.

Course Project (30%): Group project to create your own multiplayer game, with some specifications like a live view of the opponents gameplay, account system and results screen. Quite useful and fun since you are doing something hands-on, grades are given on both functionality and gameplay. (Average: 202/250)

Final (40%): The only part of this course that isn't good. The final is a 95 minute long, COMP1021 style exam, it is open note however, so just print out everything. Questions range from extremely easy, to just annoying to do since you have to read multiple pages of code to fill in ONE blank, or read 2 pages of a .JSON file to spot ONE missing bracket, what were they thinking? (Average: 66.12/100)

I got 9% over mean, and still only a B+, disappointing.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not bad.

The first 3 labs are quite easy, and can be finished in an hour or two. The last lab is harder since it is more complex, and is split into two parts, while it isn't counted in the grade if you get full marks on the first 3 labs, it's still worth doing in my opinion.

The exam is pretty easy to prepare, go through the notes and print them out. Nothing too difficult, wish the course just skipped the exam, and counted the project instead.

Speaking of which, the project, like all projects, depends on how good your groupmates are, so there is always some risk involved. I got lucky and had great groupmates, so the workload was good (since I don't have to fix their parts).

reviews.author: elwc
reviews.title: Nice

Zoom lectures with recordings provided. Clear lecture notes, with example files. Good for beginners.

reviews.comment_teaching: Gibson's way of teaching is enjoyable, as always.
reviews.comment_grading:
4 Graded Labs (Only count the highest 3 --> 30%)
Lab 2 Hammer Game
Lab 3 Jumping Game
Lab 4 Gem Rush!
Lab 5+6 Chatroom

Mini-project (30%)

Final Exam (40%)

I don't have enough data to accurately judge the grading. It feels like quite leng. But I can guarantee that it is at least fair.
reviews.comment_workload:
5 easy labs. Each takes around 2 hours.
Final Exam
The workload is not heavy for the components above.

For project, it depends on how big the scope is defined. If you make a complicated game, that would be a C because you may need to work on it for a couple of days. If you plan to make a simple one, that would be a B workload.

reviews.author: samlcy
reviews.comment_content:
Teaching about the HTML, CSS, Javascript, JQuery
also, include little bit PHP and HTTP
The first 2 weeks will finish all basic HTML element usage
Next 1~2 weeks for the Js and JQ
Then will use 2~3 weeks teach Bootstrap and CSS for better vision website
For the remaining part, teach basic PHP server and usage(get sth from POST/GET), use Ajax make an interactive website
reviews.comment_teaching:
always make a joke with students,
using funny examples to explain some idea
the notes are quite good, but extra learning from the internet still required
reviews.comment_grading:
feel good
MT and EXAM following the teaching material, with the open book,u always can get the answer and marks,
my group project is a game, most of the function working well but sometimes got the little bug, still got close to full marks, try to add more feature on the project.
In my memories,
all lab got 90~100mark
project 24/25
midterm and exam above around 1 SD(10 marks sth)
The grade is A-
reviews.comment_workload:
quite easy
no homework
only 3 lab exercise
one project for 1~3 people in the group, have about 5 weeks to finish  
open book MT and EXAM

reviews.author: A0
reviews.comment_content:
HTML, CSS, JavaScript, jQuery, AJAX, SVG, PHP
This course only teaches the very basic in internet computing. (Especially for summer course)
It is very outdated and does not teach the more advanced ways of creating a website. (Such as node.js, angular, bootstrap, React, Angular).

But, if you choose to take this course in the regular semester, they do teach more things such as bootstrap, responsive web designs, angular js, restful api. (After all, they have more time to teach).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kennith is a great teacher.
The TA is probably the best TA ever. He would stay behind after lab (14:00) until the deadline of SVG game (24:00) to help the students who are deadline fighting. So nice :)
reviews.comment_grading:
Kennith gives out really good grades :)
Statistics:
The mean and s.d. of midterm is about 77 and 14.3.
The mean and s.d. of final is about 69.something and 11.something.

Really good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
In the summer, need to finish 3 assignments, which means that you have only a week or so to finish each assignments.

The first one is the autocomplete assignments. It is easy, but if you don't rely on sources and is unfamiliar with modifying or extending the jQuery UI's widgets, you might need to take some time to research the implementation for the assignments.

The second one is SVG game. This assignment's work load is quite high as there are a lot of requirements for the game, and debugging would take a while. Really recommend not to dead line fight. Do it as early as possible. But, doing this assignment is quite fun and enjoyable.

The third assignment is super easy. Just need to change some minor things from the labs and you're done.

Have mid term and final, but is quite easy.
Oh and also, the midterm and final are open notes, open laptop exams, but cannot connect to the internet. :)

reviews.author: Leo Chan
reviews.comment_content:
The content is really outdated. It won't have much practical use in the workplace. Might have to relearn things.
You get a lot of practice on Javascript and SVG. Not so much for jQuery, AJAX and PHP, as a result of them providing most of the code for the related assignments.
reviews.comment_teaching: He is easy to listen to. But you would learn better by reading the powerpoints alone rather that listening to him. He hardly explaining anything in detail. As a result, he often dismisses his class early, which is nice. That said, he is willing to answer questions
reviews.comment_grading: It is probably quite good for a COMP course. I am about the 33.3th percentile and got a B+. It is not hard to get A range .
reviews.comment_workload: Content-wise there's not much to this course as the exams are open-book exams. The assignments are quite troublesome and many ended up not being able to complete them. However he simplified it a lot for the summer sem and most of it can be copied from the labs.

reviews.author: elessar
reviews.title: falling behind the tide
reviews.comment_content: The content of the course falls so much behinds the tide.   The first few classes are about basic HTML, CSS,JAVASCIPT, one class for Jquery and then 4 classes for SVM. This is bbefore the midterm. After the midterm comes PHP and some theoretical stuff. The course takes too much emphasis on SVM and PHP, while it should be focusing on new languages instead.
reviews.comment_teaching: his teaching is quite well, to be honest. With everything quite clear. Nevertheless, the clearness is based on the knowledge of the listeners. If we knew the content, then everything he says makes sense. Otherwise his teaching is all messed up.
reviews.comment_grading: Objectively speaking, the grading is very nice. With mean at B+ I believe. Because of a contempt for the content of the course, I skipped most of the lectures and the labs, failed to accomplish 2 assignments, almost became the last on the list of course ranking, and got a B.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is OK. Following the  lab will help save much time. 3 Projects are ther in total. One Jquery, one SVM, one PHP.

reviews.author: CHEN_Charles
reviews.title: Great course
reviews.comment_content: Lots of things varying from html, SVG, PHP. Since it is a programming based course it requires lots of practice on the new language. This course also covers few concepts of xml and server-client interaction. A great course after all but the instructor did go to deep on every topic introduced. Those who have learned about internet programming can handle this course very easily.
reviews.comment_teaching: Good English, easy to follow. Also the professor's logic is very clear and he explained everything in simple words, so some of the complex concepts can be understood in the lecture. However, he did not explain every thing into very detailed, so students still have to spend some time on studying if you wish to learn more.
reviews.comment_grading:
18% Midterm, 36% Final, 10%+18%+18% on three projects.
I got mean on the midterm, and fine for the rest. 92% on this course and got an A+. Honestly a very good grade course.
reviews.comment_workload: Two exams are open-book open-notes, so we wouldn't have to memorize the syntax and function calls. Three projects are easy and require not much time. You can absolutely find source online :).

reviews.author: Moritz
reviews.title: Easy and interesting overview of internet technologies
reviews.comment_content:
It's a quick tour through most popular internet technologies. Starting with HTML, CSS and JavaScript going over to XML and PHP. For most topics it's just scratching the surface.

I liked the fact that jQuery was incuded as well, since it is very popular these days and allows for some cool results with few lines of code.

The XML part I found to be a little bit too detailed compared to the rest.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching in general is very good. However I found that the materials are sometimes are little old and optically not very consistent. There's quite a lot of old and deprecated stuff in the Lab code as well as on the slides. A revision for JavaScript ES6 and PHP7 would be appropriate.
reviews.comment_grading: Exams are pretty easy, but that also means that everybody does very well and it is rather hard to get a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload depends very much on how much effort you put into the lab assignments. When you copy & paste everything from Stack Overflow it's not too bad. When you really want to put work into it, it can get very exhaustive.

reviews.author: luke_lu
reviews.comment_content: The whole course is about HTML+ JS, SVG, PHP, no more advanced full-stack technic( like Negix, Node js, ssh) will be covered in the class. Students are mostly required to an application level, not much in deep knowledge needed.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I would say not so good. The professor specialized in search engine, but not very familiar with the content of the course. Be prepared to search and read online yourself. (but one can't deny that this is how a programmer should be able to do)

But TA is pretty competent though.
reviews.comment_grading:
A 15%
B 40%
C 40%
D/F 5%

I got an A
I would say this is a pretty good grade. But my view may be biased since I know most of the course material already.
reviews.comment_workload: Three assignments about each of the big chapters. They are not difficult, just a lot of coding for some of them. You can get bonuses for each of these assignments for some extra feature you implement. I would say try to add something if you have time and skill. You are likely to get a bonus.

reviews.author: Âπ≥Âá°Â∞èË∑Ø‰∫∫
reviews.title: One of the BEST comp course in ust
reviews.comment_content:
Dave has changed some "old" internet stuff and updated them.

Variety of content:
start with HTML/CSS
then with JavaScript
jQuery
SVG
doing animation with CSS and SVG
DOM feature
responsive web design
AJAX
PHP
XML
HTML forms
Bootstrap
Web session
Cookies
some NodeJS
RESTful APIs
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dave is fun and speak some standard(?) English, which is very pleasant to sit in his lecture.
His teaching is great, keep showing us examples with great explanation.
This course teaches you as like you never do internet computing. So don't be scared if you forgot how to do html.
Since there are quite a lot of contents are included in the course, it does go quite fast and you have to pick up some concept in your own time.
Dave also wanted to encourage us to go to lecture, so sometimes he asked us questions, and when we got it right, we can add an extra 0.6% into our percentage. So do pay attention! But no worries if you get it wrong.

And for the TAs, Sophia and Young, they are both helpful and they guide you through the lab exercises during the lab section. But to me,  they went through the lab a bit too fast therefore I did easily got lost.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 graded lab (9% each) - 27%
(you can't choose which 3, they stated it inside the lab when you do it)
a project (project itself 20%, propose your idea 4%) - 24%
(you can do it on your own or a maximum of two groupmate)
(most people did this on their own in this sem)
midterm - 22%
final - 27%

I got a B- with a percentage of around 77.84%, mean is around 79.753%.
reviews.comment_workload:
This course is quite packed so you have to pick up some concept in your own time.
Labs are quite hard in my opinion, but TAs will help you but still, stick with lecture notes and W3SCHOOL.
You need to propose your own project, but just handle your part as a big lab exercise. I did it on my own and mine is quite sh__ but I got a full 24%.
And exams, they are hard. Although they are open books, we don't have much time to flip and find answers. Questions are short, and do really test your understanding. For example, mc ask you about the output of code, gives you four pieces of code and ask which is the only one that works... etc etc

reviews.author: HokJa
reviews.title: YOU SHOULD TAKE THIS
reviews.comment_content:
HTML, CSS , JavaScript, jQuery, AJAX, SVG, Cookies and moreeee
The course is pretty basic (and old fashioned)
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor will give examples and explain in detail so it's pretty good. but its a 9am lesson so i dont have much memories about teaching (only been to 3-4 lessons)
reviews.comment_grading:
its pretty good, never thought of getting an a range lol

my marks:
project 1:105/100 mean:100.4
project 2:91/100 mean:92
project 3:100/100 mean:93.8
midterm: 80/100 mean:70.9
final: 82/100 mean:75.7
-> A-
reviews.comment_workload:
exams are pretty easy and its open notes open book so make sure you organise it and bring everything in

never been to labs, they dont take attendance and it just help you to understand more about assignments (they will put lab solution online too)

assignments are rough lol
need to spend whole night to finish it
so i give this course a workload of B
